column4: I'd really rather not waste everyone's time by posting my question repeatedly to thepoint that nobody reads what I say.
it's considered good form (in this channel) to repeat a question about once every 15 minutes until you get a solution (or give up)....
Yeah, I know. You don't happen to remember me from a month or so ago with the major sound issues?
name was probably Spaztic_One if not this
my memory isn't best :-). Did we solve it?
no, not really. But we unbroke it from when we did try and fix it and it all went to crap... and I think it was a little better as well. =)
sound really is still a problem in most linuxes unfortunately...
Yeah, I know. It's not bugging me that much currently.
welcome back anyway. Got a ubuntu question for us?
Yeah, monitor problems. Comp thinks that the max resolution is 640x480, which is below the minimum reported res on other computers (800x600).
it's a new hardware setup?
everything is the same except that I am now on Linx, and the monitor is different than the previous one.
see if there's something in the above that helps...
Been given that 3 times before, not counting this one, or the time that I found the wiki page before I got on IRC.
However, i'm not a very well versed Linux user. Perhaps if you were to lead me along while going through it?
sounds like you need expert help. You need to put all stuff we've mentioned above into a single query and post it here every 15 minutes until Someone Who Knows shows up...
I think its that I'm not entirely sure what all of the xrand and various things within the command are, or how to use them properly. I kind of get lost.
Hmm. I just looked at the man page, xrandr *is* a complex beastie...
Yeah, have you any experience with it?
none at all :-)
So you wouldn't be likely to help me understand what its talking about, would you?

Oh, ok, so I just figured something out. I "borrowed" a monitor from one of the other computers and hooked it up as well. It has a default res pf 1280x1024, and is identified as dell blah blah blah. The other monitor is identified as CRT-0, which signifies an error.
hey, you there?
